newsitem.title: USA: Japanese communications satellite blasts off.
newsitem.headline: Japanese communications satellite blasts off.

text.p: An Atlas 2AS rocket streaked through the Florida evening sky on Sunday carrying a Japanese-owned communications and broadcasting satellite into orbit.

The Lockheed Martin Corp. rocket, fitted with solid rocket motors for extra boost, lifted off its Cape Canaveral launch pad at 9:15 p.m. EDT (0115 GMT), carrying the Superbird-C satellite for Space Communications Corp. of Toyko.
About 33 minutes later the rocket ejected the satellite into an egg-shaped temporary orbit. The 6,902-pound (3,131 kg) satellite was to later maneuver itself into a circular 22,300 mile high orbit.
Superbird C, along with two sister satellites, will provide digital broadcasting and business communications services throughout Japan and across the Asia-Pacific region, including Hawaii.
The liftoff was delayed two days by a technical problem on the launch pad and stormy weather.
It was the 31st consecutive successful launch for the Atlas rocket, which started life in the 1950s as an intercontinental ballistic missile.
